subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: ... I was certainly not advocating this, and I don t believe Kent was either. Making *all* methods protected is just as dangerous as invoking YAGNI every time
messageBody:
On 10/31/05, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> > Basic real world: you can never anticipate how future users will use
> your
> > software, so don't make their lives too difficult.
>
> If someone presents a valid, not-too-weird use case that requires
> exposing a protected method, then by all means make the method
> protected. But don't make everything protected just because you think
> someone, somewhere might one day want to use it.


I was certainly not advocating this, and I don't believe Kent was either.

Making *all* methods protected is just as dangerous as invoking YAGNI every
time to justify making *no* methods protected.

I just have a fundamental dislike for knee-jerk reactions that drive design
principles, and YAGNI is one of those.

I don't design with one liners, I use my brain and my experience to decide
in every single case if such or such method should be protected. Sometimes,
I will indeed decide that I will probably not need it later, and other
times, I will leave the door open for future extensions even though I can't
really see one myself just now.


If the sheer size of
> the resulting classes doesn't seem reason enough, then consider that you
> probably haven't designed the method correctly for extension in the
> first place.


You would probably be surprised by how well it works in practice. Many
times, I've been able to pull off something very simple just because the
author of the code I was using had the good idea to make that method
protected.

Again, my point to you is simply: don't make YAGNI an absolute rule,
because there are no absolute rules in development.


Methods provided in advance of an actual use case are
> unlikely to fit the use cases that do arise.


My experience is just the opposite.


> We can't all be experts in everything.


Exactly. Hence, making your methods protected is not always a bad
decision.



Agility accepts that we
> don't know everything, we can't predict the future, we don't get
> anything right the first time


Again: all good arguments to use protected more often than not.

--
Cédric
